title: Why is “you” sung as 'chu' in some songs? - Quora

response.answer_text: As several have said, it has to do with the language and sounds. The way you speak and the way the listener hears it. “Want you” spoken quickly blends together. You hear a “tyu” sound which comes across as “chu”. This is much more common in popular music where the vocalist is not classically trained. Seldom will you hear it in classical music because vocalists in that genra tend to enunciate their words more carefully. Also, even if Robin Zander is clearly saying “ I. Want. You. To. Want. Me. “ into the microphone, the effects, distortion, distance, surrounding crowd noise, etc., will most likely cause you to hear, “ah wan chu to wan mee”.

“I wan chu to want me…” It’s a slurring effect resulting from the difficulty in going from the ‘T’ sound with the tongue pressed against the upper front gum to the pursed-lip, tongue back ‘U’ sound. Try it - say the clipped ‘want you’ then say the more slurred and easier to pronounce ‘wan chu’ paying attention to all the moves your mouth an tongue have to go through for each variant. ‘Want you’ is 4 phonemes wah-n-t-u and ‘wan chu’ is only 3 (wah-n-chu) and much easier to sing. The next phrase in that song “I need you to to need me”, ‘need you’ is pronounced in only 2 phonemes: ‘nee’ and ‘dyu’, so you have two forms of you, chu and dyu, in that one line alone. If sung with ‘proper’ pronunciations, the lyric sounds formal and stilted.
